headline: Quick and Easy Pancit
description: This pancit recipe is easy to make with stir-fried chicken, shredded cabbage, and sliced carrots tossed with rice noodles and flavored with soy sauce.

video.description: This quick and easy recipe for pancit will remind you of island fiestas! Simply stir-fry the ingredients together for a tasty noodle dish.
video.name: How to Make Quick and Easy Pancit

name: Quick and Easy Pancit
recipeIngredient: 2 cups diced cooked chicken breast meat
2 lemons - cut into wedges, for garnish

recipeInstructions.text: Place rice noodles in a large bowl; cover with warm water and let soften for 8 to 10 minutes. Drain and set aside.

Meanwhile, heat oil in a wok or large skillet over medium-low heat. Add onion and garlic; cook and stir until onion is tender, about 3 to 5 minutes. Stir in chicken, cabbage, carrots, and soy sauce. Cook until cabbage begins to soften. Toss in noodles and cook, stirring constantly, until heated through.
Transfer pancit to a serving dish and garnish with lemon wedges.

review.reviewBody: I made my this for my boyfriend and I. We both thought it was very bland. We tried doctoring it with chicken broth like others suggested. We even tried adding more generous amounts of garlic and soy sauce. Nothing really helped.
Try with any of the following: Cashews Peanuts Thin sliced mushrooms Worcestershire sauce instead of soy.

I first tried pancit as a child at a local AZ restraunt owned by a family friend from Guam when they shut down a few years back I was devastated but then I found this recipe and now I can share it with everyone I'm new to cooking and I love how easy it is I have been seeing everyone say how long the noodles are and yes while I do agree I actually like them long. We have recently been putting our own spin on this we use Napa cabbage and red onion really really good and I know red onion is not everyone's cup of tea it cooks down enough that you don't taste it

It's a good recipe but sometimes it dry. When I make it I add low sodium chicken broth, about a cup maybe a little less. This adds the needed moisture the pancit noodles needs. This should resolve a dry pancit, but remember to soak the noodles when you begin. The noodles need to soak in warm or hot water. I do recommend you them in half or 3rds. Garnish with sliced hard-boiled eggs and sliced scallions and lemon slices. That's how my late grandfather made it. He cooked for the family. Enjoy. Hope this works for you.
The recipe is inaccurate. Wrong ingredient portions and no note to ensure you chop up the noodles a bit. Way too many vegetables. Way too much noodles.

I made it exactly like the recipe. It was good, but dry. I had a neighbor that used to send me a plate every time they had a poker party. Pretty sure she used fish sauce and she also had shrimp in hers.

The taste was absolutely fantastic! I didn't quite use all of the cabbage, but my head was probably more medium sized. Having said that, I think this is actually more like 12+ servings. It made a LOT of food.
It is easy but needs more moisture such as chicken broth
Love making Pancit! Truly comfort food!
Flavorless and not even close to tasting like Pancit.
I liked this a lot and made as directed. I think it needed something like a touch of oyster sauce perhaps, but only a little. I like that it is such a healthy dish and plan to make it again.
I would use extra chicken and add some other spices for it.
Used ramen noodles b/c they are cheaper and easier to work with...

We made the recipe exactly as written. We really wanted to like this dish as we enjoy pancit when we eat out but instead, we found this bland without the addition of ginger, and even then it was just "meh". I really wonder why when others rave about it.
Had issues with the noodles. Softening and then draining turned into a large gooey lump of noodles that would not break up.

I made sure that the chicken was half-way cooked, before I added the carrots and cabbage. Also, I think I added too many noodles in the end. I used water to soften the entire mixture once every thing was added to the wok.
Authentic, flavorful, and easy to follow recipe.
An amazing dish! I added a little extra low sodium soy sauce. Perfect light dinner. Super easy

Simple, quick and delicious. I was unsure about the Maggi sauce instead of soy, and so only used 1 TBS, but boy does it work in this recipe. I will add the full 2 TBS next time, and there will definitely be a next time. Thank you for this recipe

This was great tasting, very quick and inexpensive. It reminds me of ramen noodles, just less soupy, waaay more flavorful and much healthier. Instead of vegetable oil, I used the chicken drippings I had left over from roasting the chicken thighs I used for this recipe, which amped up the chicken-y deliciousness.
I made it and it was very good but it needed more sauces and spices. And the rest of the family liked it.
This was easy to make and tasted delicious! Made it to the recipe. Everyone loved it!
I loved this recipe! My husband is not a fan for Asian style food, but he really liked this. Next time I'll add just a little more chicken!
Delish hot or cold.

My husband enjoyed this and I will make it again. We took other reviewers suggestion of using a coleslaw mix to save time, and added bean sprouts. We did use a low sodium soy sauce which I think was a mistake. I will use regular soy sauce next time.

I made it and loved it personally! As my son does not eat carrots so he did not eat it, but he did love the noodles as I soaked them in the chicken stock from boiling the breast in! My mom wasn't a big fan either because she said she did not like the flavor, not sure why not because I personally thought it was fabulous!! Great job!

Very easy to make. 
If you’re making it and never tried it then it might not be something you’ll want to make. This dish is very popular amongst us Filipinos and it’s usually made during birthdays or gatherings. 

I like using pork because it’s more flavorful than chicken. My mom used to make it with pork and shrimp. Also, very good. 
I also use the packet that’s in the Asian isle that’s from the mama sitar’s line called chopsuey/pancit canton. This will help with the taste! 

Hope this helps!
Awesome starter recipe! I added in some fish sauce, Maggi seasoning, shrimp and soft boiled eggs and it was incredible
It did need some tweaks, but very few. Absolutely needed more soy sauce, also add some patis for some extra flavor kick.

I didn’t have all the exact ingredients, but I had all the seasoning parts and added some more, but I still found it a bit bland. I think I will try it again and add a few things. It has some promise, but just needed a little extra “oomph.”
I didn't find that this recipe had much flavor. Thank goodness for the lemon because it did add some taste, but I won't be making it again.

Wow this was really good. I followed the instructions pretty exactly. I did serve it with sliced green onions on the side to add and they were good to have. Also I did use the lemon slices and it added a nice freshness with the squeeze of lemon. The only real difference was that I added a little bit of chicken broth at the end because it seemed a little dry. Not much, just enough to moisten it a bit. I will be making this again as it was so good and everyone liked it.
Better with just 8oz of rice noodles. Terrific otherwise!

Easy to make! Tastes so light and fresh with the lemon garnish drizzled over it. Probably easily serves 5-6.
This was my first attempt so I have nothing to compare it to, but we love it!
I plan to try it with shrimp next.
Excellent. Used red cabbage though. Gavw it a lot more color.
Very delicious
Great recipe. Used Silver Swan soy sauce and Bihon noodles, added celery and black pepper, then subbed in green onions. Yum! Even my pickiest eater loved it!

I will be changing a few things next time but I will use this as a guide. 1. Ill make/use broth after I sauté the onions and garlic 2. add veggies and meat 3. Remove contents from broth and soak my noodles in the broth not just water. Then add all together
I made this recipe twice and both have ended up bland. It definitely isn’t like the pancit I’ve had in whole life. Maybe I’ll it fish sauce next time or add knorr.
I used peanut oil instead, 4 tablespoons. I also used a little more soy sauce and used pre cooked seasoned shredded chicken. It came out delicious!!!

Delicious! Very large servings- halved everything except soy sauce and garlic and it was enough for around 5 people. Also cooked chicken in the same pan used to cook everything else (w/o washing in between) to add more chicken flavor. Don't forget to add some salt with each new addition to the pan and some pepper when finished and it's amazing!

This recipe needs more onion than called for. And definitely more soya sauce ( at least 3 times what the recipe calls for).
I would agree it was bland. 
I would recommend 4 things:
- add onion
- add soya sauce until all noodles are covered and brown in color from the soya
- use good quality soya with less sodium ( Kikkoman is the best)
- cut the noodles in half before soaking in warm water

Very quick, easy and tasty! I tweaked it a bit by adding a few drops of fish sauce, but it would have been fine without it. I was not very happy with the ratio of noodles to everything else. I will use half the amount of noodles next time.
We made this once. It was a solid “good”. Will maybe make it again sometime.
Will definitely make this again. I am very new to cooking and this was just my speed.

Followed a recipe online, but I added a bit of my cooking flair! I also added sliced mushrooms, chopped green peppers and small shrimp, plus a little bit of Hoisin Sauce and Teriyaki Sauce. It came out awesome!
wonderful recipe, I followed instructions and I came out very good. have made it twice
Easy steps to follow, just takes a bit of time to prepare. Would make again for sure!
It was easy once all the veggies were prepped. I added snow peas, chicken and shrimp. It tasted very much like authentic pancit that I have had. I will definitely make again. It was yummy. It

This is my second time making it and it's so good! The mixture of soy sauce, garlic, onion and lemon juice are what make the dish. It only needed a sprinkle of salt to make the taste pop. I just used green onion and shrimp. I'll never have to order takeout noodles again!
Absolutely perfect recipe. Now in the regular rotation - my kids LOVE it! And it's easy!!
Nice recipe! My Aunt tried to teach me how to make Pancit but I would forget. This is a great reminder to get me started

I reduced the noodles to 8oz (used the thinnest rice noodles), the cabbage to about 3/4 of a head, increased the chicken to 3 cups total and left the quantities of everything else the same. I also added a healthy amount of ground fresh chili paste. As others have noted, this is a really flexible recipe. It's so good and easy it's on the menu a couple of times each month.

We added chopped red and green peppers to saute with the onions in olive oil, along with a splash of sesame oil. Soaked the broken rice noodles for over an hour to soften. For simplicity, we shredded the carrots in a food processor. We purchased 1 bag fresh coleslaw mix from the Produce department so we wouldn't have to slice the cabbage. We used chopped garlic from a jar, along with additionally adding some oyster and hoisin sauces. Added cracked blacked pepper at the end and omitted the lemons (hubby doesn't like). Next time, I think I'll buy a Costco rotisserie chicken and debone to save some work.
YUM
It is good, but a bit dry. As someone already noted in the previous reviews, stock is missing. Also added bell pepper which made it simply amazing.

This very basic recipe is easy & tasty. Here's my spin on it to save time & make it even a bit better. I don't cut up carrots & cabbage- Buy a bag of coleslaw from the produce section of the grocery store. It's the same thing but already thinly cut for you. When getting your noodles pick up a bottle of fish sauce. A few squirts of this will add a yummy flavor to the dish. Serve with soy sauce & lemon or lime wedges. Enjoy!
This was really delicious.
Added a dash of Sesame oil too. & more soy sauce. Family enjoyed it. Thanks for the recipe.
We love this recipe. I add a little chicken broth at the end and a splash more soy sauce but otherwise it’s delicious.
It was very easy and so good.
I blew my husband away with this recipe. We both loved it! The noodles came out great. Who needs a restaurant when you can make it at home. Yummy!

Well I made my first attempt to make pancit. I think something was missing, it looked great but was tasting a little bland, my daughter works with some phillpinos and has had their pancit. She added a little hoisin sauce and now it taste great.
I accidently used 1/2 cup soy sauce and it was a good mistake. I will be making it again.
I make this all the time now! Leftovers warm up great and it's quick, easy and cheap! Everyone I make this for begs for more!
Oh my god, this was just like my lola used to make! Utter perfection.
This is just like the pancit I was taught to make... easy and so delicious! Equally good using shrimp or pork.
Too many noodles and fairly bland. Won't be making it again.

Aptly named. Very quick, very easy. Prep time is where all the work is. I exclude onions, except green onions as a garnish. I also pre-cook and hand-shred the chicken. I save the broth to add later to prevent the noodles from drying out. I also recommend sprinkling dried garlic on top. My credo is you can never have too much garlic. It's my wife's favorite and she has several of her friends asking me to make it for them. It's the closest I've come to my late Mom's version.

It turned out great and it was delicious. I sautéed the onion and garlic with the chicken, and then separately again with the carrots and snow peas, and then again with the cabbage all separately just to get the whole flavor set into them.
We tried this dish at our school multi cultural fair and all of my boys loved it. I found the recipe on this website and it was a big hit- all three of my boys had seconds. Thank you!
Added an extra cup of soy sauce and it came out GREAT!!! Definitely will use this recipe again!!!

This turned out awesome, even my Filipino wife loved it and her Mom and Dad both make excellent pacit! This does make a bunch, plenty for a gathering or for several meals. I did make few adjustments to the recipe:

Only needed two carrots and half an onion (was a larger medium sized one), also got a head of cabbage about softball size and only needed about 2/3rds of it. Added thinly sliced celery, green onions and salad shrimp too.

I ended up boiling the chicken first and then cut it up. Boiled water with about a cup of chicken broth in it then removed it from the heat and put the noodles in it. Definitely break the noodles up so they aren't super long.

Used more like 1/3 of a cup of soy sauce and sauteed everything but the meat together at the same time til softened a bit and then added the chicken and maybe a 1/4 to 1/3 cup more soy sauce and cooked a few more minutes then added the noodles and stirred/cooked until heated and all noodles were coated in the soy sauce.
Lovely to make..... added lime to it also. Tasted beautiful. Partner and friend absolutely love it. Quick and easy to make. Smelt like something I had brought from a Chinese restaurant ????
Restaurant quality recipe! It came delicious. I used Napa cabbage and I added a scrambled egg to the mix b4 adding noodles. I will be making this again!
Amazing!!! Although I substituted carrots(which I hate) with broccoli (which I love). Definitely my go to dish from now on
Perfect recipe! I substituted leftover grilled pork chop for the chicken.

Family loves Pancit!
Although, I didn't how much water to use when boiling the noodles...kept adding water at 1/2 cup increments. 
But overall, it turned out great and will continue to make this dish. Thanks for the recipe!
It was delicious and easy to make.
Kids loved it. Used egg noodles not glass, just what I had. Will make this fairly often for a bit. Faster and healthier than spag.

I love Pancit because you can change it up however you like it. I use packaged shredded cabbage and carrots, broccoli florets, and sometimes add snow peas during the last couple of minutes. Soaking the rice noodles is much easier than sautéing them. And this time I added a package of small, frozen and thawed shrimp instead of chicken since I was serving it with Chicken Adobo.
My husband and I love this recipe!! We wanted a little more kick, so we added two tablespoons of sriracha sauce. This is inexpensive and low calorie and we live every bite!
I have made this dish at least 6 times, it's amazing every time and very easy to make!

The only change is that I added a tad bit more (to taste) of Soy Sauce. I also added 2 fried eggs to my batch. (I fried it separately at the very end and added it evenly to the finished pancit. This was quick, easy and a huge amount for my family of 6! Thank You for this recipe!!!

This beats ANY that my family or I have ever had at any restaurant! PERIOD!
Our local Chinese restaurants call this dish Lo Mein, which we absolutely love.
The only change I made was leaving the chicken out because we ate a shrimp dinner with it.
Recipe is perfect as is.
We could eat this several times per week!

Great recipe! This was my first time making this, and I had trouble figuring out what kind of rice noodles to buy. I ended up with a bag if "stir-fry" noodles. I wasn't sure about soaking them in hot water, because the bag instructions were to boil in water for 12-14 minutes. So, I boiled them, drained them and added them at the end. They are good, but I was hoping for a very small thin noodle....better luck next time. It ended up being GREAT! I made this as a side dish with chicken adobo. Happy family and clean plates! Happy Momma.

This was really not good. There was almost no flavor to this dish, and no matter what I did to try to rescue it with seasonings and soy sauce, it just wasn't going to cut it. Unfortunately this was a waste, as it all went into the trash.
I'm a military wife and have tried many dishes. I Asian food. I love Pancit

I'd like to say "I made it"....and I did, kinda, but I made soooo many substitutions I'm not sure I can in all honesty stay I made it. BUT, I used this recipe as a guideline and it turned out el yummo. I basically emptied the leftover vegetable drawer - zucchini, carrots, green beans, mushrooms, onion etc. I chucked in leftover chicken. I used vermicelli (see what I mean about the myriad of substitutions?) as that's what I had. Anyway, it turned out delicious. It made a huge amount - easily enough for 4-5 hungry people, and was extremely economical to make. I would say about $1 per person at the outside. 
The DH and I like things spicy so we chucked some hot sauce on there rather than extra soy sauce. Nom nom nom.

I made this for a potluck at work, and it was a huge hit and super easy to make! The only thing I did differently was add a little chicken broth when I added the noodles just to keep them from getting too dry. My rice noodles were impossible to break up prior to cooking so I just chopped them up with some kitchen shears once they were soft. Delicious! Thanks for the recipe!
Always delicious I add a little sesame oil for flavour as well, but it's an amazing dish!

Recipe easy and tasted just ok... not very flavorful. Would use again with the following changes:
Would soak the rice noodles in heated chicken broth rather than water. Would also use peanut oil rather than veggie oil. Gives it more asian flavor.

Been missing my pancit fix since I moved out of San Francisco and away from my Filipino friends. Made this to take to a pot luck tomorrow. I will let you know how it goes. I have had two servings myself. I'd say it is absolutely a 5.

This is a great dish. Instead of the special noodles, I used a cheap pack of ramen noodles. I cooked them until loosened then added some oil to get a little crisp on them. The rest I did exactly the same as posted. Will be adding this one to the rotation.
Easier than I thought. Lots of flavor. Definitely a keeper.
It was delish!!!

I have always been scared to attempt pancit but this recipe was super easy and delicious! I had to go to a local oriental market to find bihon rice noodles. I filled a large plastic container with warm, on the cusp of hot, water from my tap and covered it with a cloth towel. I checked it in ten minutes and they were good to go! I drained them and set them aside. I don't like using canned chicken so I bought 1.5lbs of chicken breast, cut it into cubes, sautéed it and then set it aside to be added with the noodles. I cooked the garlic and onion in the chicken drippings. A lot of other reviews said green onion but I went with a small diced yellow and it was great. I also added snow peas and water chestnuts (drained of course) because I love them. They all cooked really evenly and added great texture. I am a huge fan of Bragg's Liquid Aminos as a soy sauce substitute but it would have made it WAY too salty so I used Yamasa brand soy sauce. I put in 1c of soy sauce total instead of the suggested 1/4c. I started with 1/4 but it seemed too dry. After everything was mixed in and served up I grabbed my bowl and put a few drops of sriracha in. It gave the dish a little kick. This is definitely an easy, wonderful base recipe! Will make again.
I used more garlic than the recipe called for and left sriracha on the table as a condiment. People loved it!

I'm more of a fan of pancit Canton vice bihon rice noodles. I use the Orchids brand 'Philippine Style Noodles'. Whether with pork or chicken, this recipe is fast and easy. I don't soak the noodles but add them at the end and let the rising steam soften them.
